items.title: 6 Retail Trends to Watch in 2026: AI ROI, Value-Seeking Consumers, Mall Renaissance
items.summary: Retail Dive identifies six major trends for 2026: AI adoption faces ROI scrutiny as the industry shows higher organizational restrictions and slower integration compared to other sectors. Consumer spending growth slows to 1.5% (down from 2.5-3% in 2023-2024) amid wage growth of 3.5% barely exceeding inflation. Shopping centers undergo transformation with mixed-use development and B-mall strategic investments. Dynamic pricing regulation expands with NY's algorithmic pricing disclosure requirements. Same-day delivery accelerates with Amazon's 30-minute delivery and Walmart's multi-channel fulfillment. Tariff impacts continue as forward-bought inventory depletes.
items.raw_content: AI Growth & ROI Questions: The retail industry saw significant AI adoption during 2025 holiday season but faces challenges - 'retail industry faces higher organizational restrictions, more skepticism, and slower integration' per Wharton study. Persistent Value-Seeking: Moody's expects real personal consumption growth to slow to 1.5% in 2026. Navy Federal Credit Union reported spending up 11% at Amazon and 12% at Costco. Mall Renaissance: Shopping centers increasingly viewed as viable platforms for reinvention. Dynamic Pricing Regulation: NY implemented algorithmic pricing disclosure requirements in 2025, expected to expand in 2026. Same-Day Delivery: Amazon launched 'Amazon Now' (30-minute delivery). Tariff Impacts: New inventory costs rise due to tariffs. PitchBook forecasts K-shaped economy favoring AI-adjacent companies.

items.title: Retail Returns Expected to Spike 25-35% Post-Christmas 2026
items.summary: Post-Christmas returns (Dec 26-31) projected to spike 25-35% compared to earlier season levels, with January returns remaining elevated by 8-15% in first two weeks. Returns declined 2.5% YoY from Nov 1-Dec 12. Device usage patterns show 39% of returns on mobile vs 50%+ online spending on mobile - consumers prefer desktop for returns. Online spending totaled $187.3B (Nov 1-Dec 12), up 6.1% YoY. Home products led growth: refrigerators/freezers up 400%, security systems up 380%, washers/dryers up 380% YoY. 2024 saw ~$890B in returns (17% of annual retail sales) per NRF.

Home products: refrigerators/freezers +400%, security systems +380%, washers/dryers +380% YoY. 2024 returns: ~$890B (17% annual retail sales).

items.title: AI-Powered Recommendations Redefining Shopping: Multimodal Visual Discovery and AI Agents
items.summary: Three major AI trends reshaping retail in 2026: (1) Multimodal Visual Discovery - Pinterest's proprietary model outperforms leading models by 30+ points on shopping recommendation relevance. (2) AI Agents as Decision Intermediaries - AI performs product comparison and recommendation tasks, shifting brand competition from human attention to algorithmic placement. (3) Hyper-Personalized AI-Generated Media - generative video platforms create seamlessly integrated product narratives. Younger consumers increasingly research on TikTok/Instagram. Critical gap: AI struggles with human emotion/meaning interpretation, making brand storytelling essential.

Pinterest VP Julie Towns: 'Our proprietary multimodal visual search model outperforms leading models by 30+ points on shopping recommendation relevance.' Ogilvy's Griffin Smith: 'Brands compete for attention and algorithmic visibility. Shaping agent configuration becomes critical.' Younger consumers research on TikTok/Instagram. AI struggles with human emotion/meaning interpretation.

items.title: Gen Z Shopping Behavior 2026: 56% Social Commerce Rate, 82% Plan to Buy Dupes
items.summary: Gen Z social media buyer rate reaches 56% vs 36.5% total population. 61% lead all generations in AI use for shopping. 82% plan to purchase dupes during holidays. 68% of millennials and Gen Z buy secondhand. Physical retail remains important for high-ticket items. Gen Z digital buyers projected to reach 90.3% by 2029. Platform penetration: Instagram 74.8%, TikTok 69.8%, YouTube 90%+, Reddit 62% (18-24), Snapchat 52%, Discord 31.2%. Average daily media consumption: 6.9 hours. 89% are second-screen users. 96.3% watch digital video. 52% feel closer to creators than celebrities.

Instagram 74.8%, TikTok 69.8%, YouTube 90%+. Average media: 6.9 hrs/day. 89% second-screen users. 52% closer to creators than celebrities. Marketing recommendations: authentic creators, multi-platform, remove friction, BNPL, sustained social commitment, optimize for AI chatbots.

items.title: AI Shopping Tools Gain Traction: 20% Cyber Week Orders AI-Influenced, $20.9B in 2026
items.summary: Salesforce reports 20% of global Cyber Week orders influenced by AI and agents. Adobe reported 670% increase in AI traffic to US retail sites during holiday season, but 'number using AI chatbots remains modest.' AI platforms expected to account for 1.5% of total retail ecommerce sales in 2026 ($20.9B), nearly quadruple 2025. Shoppers prefer retailer-owned AI (Amazon Rufus, Walmart Sparky) over standalone platforms. Amazon introduced Auto Buy button. OpenAI launched Instant Checkout. Perplexity deployed agentic shopping tool. Major retailer pushback: Shopify and Amazon resist external AI agents. Walmart restricted agents from checkout/orders.

Walmart restricted checkout access. Risk: losing shopper insights, reduced exposure, compromised attribution. Strategy: generative engine optimization (GEO).

items.title: Holiday E-commerce Sales Hit $258 Billion, Mobile 56.4% of Spend
items.summary: 2025 holiday e-commerce sales reached $258 billion (Adobe Analytics). Cyber Monday: $14.25B (+7.1%), Black Friday online: $11.8B (+9.1%). Smartphone transactions accounted for 56.4% of online spend, up from 54.5% in 2024. Mobile commerce continues to dominate holiday shopping, representing majority of transaction volume for first time in e-commerce history.

items.title: Online Transactions Outweigh Physical Sales for First Time in Discretionary Categories
items.summary: Major milestone: Excluding autos, gas, and much of grocery, online and digitally influenced transactions outweigh purely physical sales for first time in 2026. In discretionary, higher-margin categories (apparel, electronics, home, beauty, general merchandise), online accounts for 30-50% of sales. AI agents compress discovery, comparison, and decision-making into single continuous process that doesn't require store visit. Smart consumer agents and autonomous supply chains transform retail operations.

items.title: Circular Economy Retail Expanding: UK Strategy Unveiled, Market to Reach $798B by 2029
items.summary: UK Government established Circular Economy Taskforce to develop first comprehensive strategy for transitioning to circular economy, expected to be unveiled in 2026. Global circular economy market valued at ~$517.79B in 2025, expected to reach $798.3B in 2029. From 2026, UK begins phasing in UK Sustainability Reporting Standards (UK SRS), ISSB-aligned framework for sustainability reporting. ESG especially material in retail/CPG around packaging and circular economy. Consumer preference measurably shifting toward products with credible sustainability evidence. McKinsey/NIQ find higher sales growth for CPG items with ESG-related claims, consumers willing to pay premium.

items.title: Gen Alpha Retail Preference: 66% Prefer In-Store Shopping, See Retail as 'Playgrounds'
items.summary: Two-thirds (66%) of Gen Alpha parents say their child prefers shopping in-store, with top reasons being family time outside home (47%) and shopping trips are fun (45%). Gen Alpha sees retailers like Sephora and Target as 'playgrounds' or 'amusement parks,' craving human interaction and tactile experiences. Digital discovery: among 11-14 year-olds, 48% learn about products from influencers/internet personalities, rivaling in-store discovery. YouTube dominates at 56%, TikTok 22%, Snapchat/Instagram 12% each. Gen Alpha will rival spending power of Gen Z and Millennials by 2029, numbering 2.5B+ globally. 46% interested in climate/environment, 92% understand importance of authenticity. 49% trust influencer recommendations as much as family. 66% prefer spending on real-world items vs digital-only.

items.title: BNPL to Account for 25% of E-commerce Transactions by 2026, Market $28.44B
items.summary: Global BNPL revenues projected at $28.44B in 2026. BNPL expected to account for roughly 25% of all e-commerce transactions by 2026. Leading platforms: Klarna, Afterpay, Affirm (Amazon's choice), Sezzle, PayPal Pay Later. Technology integration: AI underwriting and fraud detection models enable real-time credit checks in milliseconds. Expanded use cases: shifting beyond discretionary retail into groceries, healthcare, education, travel. Physical/digital integration: BNPL moving to in-store POS terminals, mobile wallets (Apple Pay, Google Pay), physical smart cards (Klarna Card, Afterpay Card). Regulatory developments: Australia's Treasury confirmed BNPL will fall under National Consumer Credit Protection Act by 2026. 2025-2026 brings decisive regulatory harmonization in US, EU, Australia.

items.title: Retail Media Networks to Reach $71.09B in 2026, Amazon 79.7% Market Share
items.summary: US advertisers will spend $71.09B on retail media in 2026 ($60.32B in 2025), 17.8% YoY growth outpacing social network and search ad spending growth. Commerce media will account for 15.6% of total ad revenue in 2025, 17.2% by 2030. Amazon Ads dominates with 79.7% US retail media share in 2025, Walmart Connect 8.0% (5x Target Roundel's 1.5%). Challenge: fragmentation - each retailer operates own platform with different formats, measurement standards, buying interfaces.

items.title: Experiential Retail Pop-Up Market to Reach $144.3B by 2032, 81% Willing to Pay More
items.summary: Pop-up retail market expanding from $95B in 2025 to $144.3B by 2032. Immersive entertainment market moving toward $442.1B by 2030 at 26.3% CAGR. 81% of global consumers willing to pay more for elevated shopping experiences. Drop culture thrives in 2026: shoppers love exclusivity, urgency, limited access aligned with short-term experiential retail. Pop-up shops are 'phygital' touchpoints, activating online communities offline with instant gratification and immersive storytelling. Phygital retail strengthens omnichannel: 73% shoppers move across channels before purchasing, 91.75% Gen Z interested in AR-driven shopping. Coach's Zero10 AR mirrors increased window engagement 93.5%, foot traffic 50%. Decathlon offers Apple Vision Pro virtual showrooms. Experiential retail pop-ups can lift visits and sales by ~30%. Retail becoming cultural hub, temporary spaces create urgency and foster community.

items.title: AR Shopping Market to Exceed $11B by 2028, Virtual Try-On Boosts Conversion 94%
items.summary: AR shopping market projected to grow over $11B by 2028. Global VR market projected to reach $123.06B by 2032. 2026 experiential retail innovation focuses on spatial computing, WebAR, AI-driven personalization. Spatial Computing: Apple Vision Pro enables users to 'pull' products and inspect in 3D space. WebAR: AR shopping apps run directly in mobile browser, accessible with link, no download needed. AI-Driven Personalization: AI generates custom AR experiences on-the-fly, virtual mannequins suggest outfits based on calendar/weather. Virtual try-on: AR for makeup, eyewear, clothing, shoes (Sephora, L'Oreal, Warby Parker pioneers). Benefits: reduces return rates up to 25%, products with AR content show 94% higher conversion (Shopify study), 3D previews: 65% more likely to purchase, returns drop 20%. 71% of consumers intend to shop more frequently when retailers introduce VR (PwC). By 2030, experts predict VR commonplace: routine VR fitting rooms, virtual malls, metaverse product launches.

Driving factors: labor shortages, rising costs, robots/AI offset staffing challenges for repetitive tasks.

items.title: Walmart Deploys Electronic Shelf Labels to 2,300 Stores Enabling Dynamic Pricing
items.summary: Walmart rolling out electronic shelf labels (ESLs) across 2,300 stores in US, enabling real-time pricing based on demand, inventory, competition. Walmart clarifies it doesn't use surge pricing/dynamic pricing tactics, but customers remain skeptical. Competitors including Kroger, Whole Foods, Lidl following suit with ESL deployment. Regulatory scrutiny: lawmakers raised concerns about retailers using surveillance technology like facial recognition to change prices for customers. Kroger and Walmart landed in hot water over reports considering surveillance tech for dynamic pricing. Washington considering event-based limits restricting surge multipliers during peak moments. Federal proposals targeting AI-based price manipulation, focusing on fairness and consistent logic. Instacart's dynamic pricing schemes use factors: repeat customer status, proximity to competitors, behavior outside app, demographics, weather. FIFA announced 2026 World Cup tickets will use dynamic pricing.

Competitors: Kroger, Whole Foods, Lidl ESL deployment. Regulatory: surveillance tech (facial recognition) for pricing concerns. Kroger/Walmart hot water. Washington: event-based surge limits. Federal: AI price manipulation proposals, fairness focus. Instacart dynamic: repeat customer, competitor proximity, outside behavior, demographics, weather. FIFA 2026 World Cup: dynamic ticket pricing.

items.title: Omnichannel Retail Becomes Baseline Requirement, Not Differentiator in 2026
items.summary: Omnichannel retail no longer viewed as differentiator in 2025, becoming basic requirement for staying relevant in 2026. Industry forecasts suggest gap between retailers with mature omnichannel capabilities and those without will widen further in 2026. 2026 omnichannel trends: efficiency and unity. Shoppers want convenience and consistency. AI-powered overviews sit at top of search results, pushing traditional links down. Retailers must focus on AI discoverability: structured product data, rich user reviews, authoritative external signals. Best omnichannel retailers prioritize operational consistency across channels: whatever shopper sees/can do online works same in-store and vice versa. Consumers increasingly expect single experience across online platforms, mobile apps, physical stores: consistent pricing, real-time stock visibility, flexible fulfillment. Omnichannel customer of 2026 moves faster, questions more, trusts selectively, uses AI but doesn't surrender judgment. Mobile is glue between digital discovery and physical shopping. Six in ten shoppers prefer in-person shopping because they enjoy it. Gen Z and Gen Alpha expect seamless omnichannel experiences.

AI-powered overviews push links down. Focus: AI discoverability - structured data, reviews, external signals. Operational consistency: online=in-store. Expectations: single experience, consistent pricing, real-time stock, flexible fulfillment. 2026 customer: faster, questions more, selective trust, uses AI but judges. Mobile: glue digital-physical. 60% prefer in-person because enjoy. Gen Z/Alpha expect seamless omnichannel.

items.title: Retail Data Privacy as Competitive Differentiator: 13 US States Pass Privacy Legislation
items.summary: Consumer data privacy and protection no longer simply compliance concern, but marketing imperative in 2026. Companies failing to create/maintain consumer data protection plan will risk alienating significant portion of customer base. While few US consumers trust companies to use data responsibly, more than two-thirds say willing to share data if results in more personalized and rewarding customer experiences. Value exchange is critical: companies must create compelling value proposition to share data. Some consumers may switch companies based solely on how secure they believe data is. Privacy has become competitive differentiator. Retailers that proactively address privacy concerns while delivering personalized services will differentiate in market. Currently 13 states signed consumer privacy legislation into law, many others in legislative process. Best practices: consent-first model where customers opt-in, leverage technology offering insights without collecting PII (aggregated data analytics, anonymized tracking).
items.raw_content: Privacy: marketing imperative not just compliance 2026. Failure risks alienating customers. Few trust companies with data, but 2/3 willing to share for personalization/rewards. Value exchange critical: compelling proposition needed. Consumers switch based on data security perception. Privacy = competitive differentiator. Proactive privacy + personalized services = market differentiation. 13 states privacy legislation, many in process. Best practices: opt-in consent-first, leverage non-PII technology (aggregated analytics, anonymized tracking).

items.title: Agentic AI in Retail: 2026 Will Redefine How Retail Operates
items.summary: 2026 retail trends point toward landscape defined by dissolution of silos, rise of agentic AI, and demand for radical transparency. Agentic AI represents shift from reactive AI tools to proactive autonomous agents that can make decisions, take actions, complete tasks on behalf of users without constant human intervention. In retail context: AI agents can autonomously reorder products, optimize inventory across supply chain, negotiate with suppliers, personalize shopping experiences in real-time, manage pricing strategies dynamically. Represents fundamental shift in how retail operations function, moving from human-directed processes to AI-augmented/AI-led workflows.

items.title: Retail Personalization vs Privacy Tension: Two-Thirds Willing to Share Data for Rewards
items.summary: Consumers increasingly concerned about data privacy as companies seek information to power personalization. Paradox: while few US consumers trust companies to use data responsibly, more than two-thirds willing to share data if results in more personalized and rewarding experiences. Indicates critical importance of value exchange in data sharing. Retailers must balance: collecting enough data for effective personalization vs respecting privacy boundaries and building trust. Transparency about data usage, clear value propositions, giving consumers control over their data are key to navigating this tension. Companies that crack this balance gain competitive advantage; those that fail risk losing customers.

Critical: value exchange in data sharing. Balance needed: enough data for personalization vs respecting privacy/building trust. Keys: transparency about usage, clear value propositions, consumer control. Crack balance = competitive advantage. Fail = lose customers.

items.title: Physical Stores Hold Unique Value: 60% of Shoppers Prefer In-Person Because They Enjoy It
items.summary: Despite digital commerce growth, physical stores hold unique value: six in ten shoppers say they prefer in-person shopping simply because they enjoy it. Not driven by necessity or lack of digital alternatives, but by intrinsic enjoyment of physical shopping experience. Signals importance of experiential elements: tactile interaction with products, social aspects of shopping, instant gratification, entertainment value. Retailers should focus on enhancing in-store experience rather than viewing physical retail as legacy channel. Opportunities: creating engaging environments, offering experiences unavailable online, leveraging stores as fulfillment/service hubs, integrating digital tools to enhance (not replace) physical experience.

Importance of experiential: tactile interaction, social aspects, instant gratification, entertainment. Retailers: enhance in-store vs viewing as legacy. Opportunities: engaging environments, unavailable-online experiences, fulfillment/service hubs, digital tools to enhance not replace physical.

items.title: NRF 2026 Focus: Circular Retail Solutions Expand Driven by Consumer Demand and Regulation
items.summary: Circular retail solutions will expand in 2026, driven by three factors: consumer demand, economic constraints, and regulatory requirements. NRF's Center for Retail Sustainability highlights growing importance of circular economy approaches. Includes: product take-back programs, refurbishment/resale initiatives, rental/subscription models, closed-loop supply chains, sustainable packaging, extended producer responsibility. Gen Alpha characterized as first generation fully raised with global perspective and penchant for sustainability, inclusivity, social impact. For retailers, balancing affordability with operational sustainability will be paramount as they navigate economic challenges in 2026. Consumer motivations beyond price: love of family, community, seeking moments of joy determine retail interaction. AI's impact on consumer discovery changing how shoppers find trends, compare prices, make decisions through online search, review summaries.

items.title: Fashion Retail Braces for Rougher 2026: AI for Agility, Forecasting, Inventory Management
items.summary: Fashion retail anticipates challenging 2026 landscape with increased discounting pressures and market uncertainty. AI will remain key lever in 2026, not just to create new ways for consumers to shop, but to help brands become more agile through better forecasting, inventory management, and planning. Fashion-specific AI applications: demand forecasting to reduce overproduction, dynamic inventory allocation across channels, trend prediction from social media/search data, automated merchandising decisions, supply chain optimization, personalized styling recommendations. Shift from consumer-facing AI novelty to back-end operational efficiency. Critical for survival in margin-pressured environment.
